christa.title: Mnemonic Devices
christa.role: research assistant, application development and architecture, prototyping
christa.description:
Series of technology driven art installations developed under the direction of Christa Erickson. This body of work was part of Christa's solo faculty exhibition at Stony Brook University Staller Center for the Arts.

View project documentation

sub.title: Seesaw
sub.description: See/Saw is part of MNEMONIC DEVICES. The most prominent component of the work, this twelve-foot seesaw, literally requires two peoples' participation, even cooperation. The seesaw acts like a giant video switcher: the way the participants 'play' determines the sequence, direction, and speed of images projected on an adjacent screen. Imagery is shot on super8 film, lending a home movie feel, and depicting closely cropped gestures between people. With no one at 'play', the screen contains images of 'leaders' collaged from TV, film, and video games that span this century.
sub.tech: Arduino, potentiometer attached to seesaw, analog signal treatment, Max MSP Jitter

sub.title: Whirl
sub.description: In Whirl memory and nostalgia is revealed as a warped phenomena. The viewer's breath is mapped such that blowing a pinwheel controls the playback of both record player and video, warping nostalgic sound from a found record of old rhyming favorites and imagery of wildly physical play on turn of the century (19th to 20th) circle swing.
sub.tech: Arduino, piezo attached to pinwheel, analog signal treatment, Max MSP Jitter

sub.title: Debt Reducer
sub.description:
As the U.S. National debt has recently surpassed $16 trillion, living to excess and beyond our means increasingly embodies and distresses our culture.Debt Reducer invites participants to contemplate personal and collective implications of debt and our culture of over-consumption.
This piece conveys a graphic, bodily sense of debt as constraining and suffocating through its "belt tightening" device and audio-video. A motorized corset and interactive video installation responds to individual debt levels that gallery visitors submit via their cell phones. As debt is submitted, the device squeezes a bloated dress-dummy torso through an elaborate pulley and winch system. Simultaneously, video of gold foil covered chocolate coins cascades down and accumulates at different heights according to amounts of debt. Absent viewer input, it randomly scrolls through the U.S. national debt, average student loan, and median gallery visitors’ debt that is projected upon audio-video of simmering fat.
sub.tech: Adobe Director, Arduino, Voltage controlled DC motors, HTML scrapper in Java, Email / SMS parser in Python

sub.title: Web Game
sub.description: Scavenger Hunt is part of MNEMONIC DEVICES. It examines the e-rhetoric of "connection" and the collective memory of the web. The two on-site web stations (laptops on opposite ends of a table that resembles the seesaw) allow people to play a scavenger hunt game with each other or people in remote locations. It asks a series of questions that are answered via a search engine. The one who finds all the answers first wins.
sub.tech: Adobe Flex, ActionScript 3,  multi threaded server in Java SE, real time sockets

sub.title: Climate Shifts
sub.description:
We are all affected by our immediate context and its political, environmental, cultural and temporal influences. “Climate Shifts” juxtaposes various locations around the globe and their points of view through local news headlines and weather data. Differences in concerns and perspectives emerge, sometimes about the same world events, allowing a glimpse into the collective psyche of each place. How do geographically differing news sources interpret an election season? What are the primary concerns in Beirut versus Jerusalem? What events in Asia echo in Latin America?
A large umbrella acts as an overhead screen upon which the piece animates shifts through various destinations with the top of the umbrella pole acting as a locator. 'Climate' news, weather and time are gathered from real-time RSS feeds and layered over an illuminated light pollution satellite image of the globe. Time is reflected by clock hands that spin and adjust according to the time zone.
sub.tech: Adobe Flex, ActionScript 3, RSS parsing, PHP, MySQL

livecase.title: LiveCase by Google
livecase.description:
Google Live Case is a personalized case for Nexus and Pixel phones available from the Google Store. The case is fully customizable and comes with a live wallpaper to match your design. Additionally, the case packs an NFC chip, which activates the companion app. Huge was tasked with designing and building the product selection, customizer and checkout flow.
We created three different "generators" for Google. For the Places generator, users choose their device, locate and position a place on Google Maps, and choose an optional style and color scheme. Photos allowed you deck your case out with your favorite photos. Artist Collections lets you browse and select from a curated list of graphic artist.
I contributed to all areas of the product development. From setting up the CI pipeline, developing a load testing and profiling rig, 3rd party API integrations for content moderation and companion app, 3d rendering optimizations, custom shaders.
view product
livecase.tech:
Backend: Python, Golang, Google Cloud(AppEngine, Services, Task Queues, Storage, BigQuery, Datastore)
Frontend: Angular.js, Three.js, GLSL

twg.title: Think with Google
twg.description:
Think with Google is Google's unique editorial and data insights destination for marketing professionals.
I Worked as a backend lead developing custom publishing solutions on a propietary content platform, continous integration and delivery practices for the tech team and a scalable localisation platform.
I worked closely with content strategists on information architecture and translating that to efficient database designs. Mentored and helped on board new developers.
twg.tech: Python, Google Cloud(AppEngine, Services, Task Queues, Datastore)

playstation.title: First To Greatness - PS4
playstation.description:
First To Greatness is a first of it's kind site that allows gamers to upload game footage against a list of 64 challenges to become a part of PlayStation history being made on the new PS4 console.
I only joined the project in its last few weeks and helped with its launch. I helped solve front end bugs and cross browser video delivery issues on a extremely tight deadline. I implemented custom scripts to transcode a large amount of user generated videos to multiple formats right after the initial beta release.

Project Press

IGN
Joystiq
Business Insider

Project Awards

FWA SOTD
D&AD Book
Cannes Cyber Lion - Silver
playstation.tech: FFMPEG, Ruby on Rails, Active Admin CMS customizations, CSS3 animations, Javascript performance optimization

rangerover.title: Race The Sun
rangerover.description:
Race the Sun is a big, sweeping interactive film that users control via their mobile phone or keyboard.
In the experience, users follow our driver as he races to deliver a Range Rover to a hidden location before sunset. Users have the option to use their mobile phone as a second screen that allows them to play racing games within the narrative. The games call back to key features of the Sport, such as acceleration, agility and off-road capabilities.
Race The Sun was built using NodeJS and web sockets to enable the phone syncing experience.
We implemented a video playback system that incorporated multiple streaming HTML5 players to allow users to proceed through the experience quickly and with virtually no buffering. The games incorporated mobile specific technologies such as accelerometer and swipe gestures.
Thanks to HTML5 video and other modern web technologies, we were able to support a wide array of desktops and tablets, broadening our reach.
rangerover.tech: Node.js, Socket.IO, Youtube API, Backbone.js, Amazon S3 for assets, Krpano for panoramas, Nodejitsu for application hosting
rangerover.awards: FWA Site Of The Day,  FWA Mobile Site Of The Day, FWA Adobe Cutting Edge Award

nvtv.title: Nature Valley Trail View
nvtv.description:
The Trail View project was born out of Nature Valley’s commitment to nature and their mission to preserve it.
It was the first-of-its-kind hiking experience and glimpse into America’s National Parks using Street View technology, and to pull it off we hiked, climbed, and captured over 400 miles of 360° photo-views across the country.
Choosing from Grand Canyon, Yellowstone, Great Smoky Mountains and Sequoia, hikers can pick one of the parks and explore its trails in depth via a topographic map. In addition we shot and developed high-quality full 360 point-of-interest panorama photography as key call outs on the site, mixed with ambient natural sound from the respective environments. Trail View 2.0 also highlights Nature Valley’s preservation efforts, flora and fauna and mobile-optimized experience.
They ported the Street View 360 technology into creating the original,
unprecedented Trail View platform — Google

Milestones

  • 38.4 million media impressions.
  • Brand fanbase up 16,000+.
  • $1.3 mil raised and donated for conservation.
  • 10x growth in visitors.
  • Average 3:41 min spent on site following broadcast spot.
  • Featured in IDEO’s lecture series.
  • 34 awards including 2x Cannes Cyber Lions, 2x Clios, and 2x Webby wins.

Press

  • A Street View-Style Tour Of National Parks Hiking Trails, Courtesy Of Nature Valley — Fast Company
  • Marketers Promoting a Granola Bar Hit the Trails in National Parks — The New York Times
  • Hike Yellowstone From Home: Nature Valley Releases Virtual Park Tours — Condé Nast Traveler
  • Trail View captures 300 miles of US national park trails in 360 degrees — The Verge
  • Nature Valley Trail View, Celebrated Digital Campaign for the National Parks, Gets an Update — Adweek
  • Nature Valley Trail View — Think with Google
  • Nature Valley Trail View 2.0 — Think with Google
  • Nature Valley Offering ‘Street View’ for Hiking U.S. Parks — PCMag
  • SXSW: Virtually Hike National Parks With Nature Valley’s Trail View — Popular Mechanics
nvtv.tech: Ruby on Rails, Spine.js, FFMPEG, Google Maps API, Krpano, Rackspace
